{{Use Indian English|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} '''Asati''' (असाटी in [[Hindi]]) is a merchant community in [[Bundelkhand]] region of [[Madhya Pradesh]]. ==Origin== K.S. Singh KS Singh 1998, India's communities, Anthropological Survey of India mentioned that the Asatis originally hailed from a village near [[Ayodhya]] and later shifted to around [[Tikamgarh district|Tikamgarh]].They subsequently migrated throughout [[Bundelkhand]].A FIFTEENTH-CENTURY DIGAMBAR JAIN MYSTIC AND HIS FOLLOWERS, Taraj Taraj Svami and the Taraj Svami Panth, John E. Cort , Studies in Jaina history and culture: disputes and dialogues, Taylor & Francis, 25 May 2006, p.h 302 ==History== In some texts the name is given as Asahati or Asaiti. Navalshah Chanderia, who wrote Vardhamana Purana in 1768 AD at Khataura, included the Asati community among the eleven merchant communities that are partly Jain.Shri Vardhaman Purana, Ed. Pannalal Jain Sahityacharya, 1942, p.417, गृहपति आठारम तिहि शाख, उनविन्शति में नेमा भाख
वीसम नैत असैटी लहे पल्लिवार इकवीसम कहे ||
पोरवार बाइसौं धार ढढतवाल तेईस निहार
चौवीसम माहेश्वरवार इतने लौं कछु जैन लगार || {{Original research inline|date=June 2018}} Russel and Hiralal in 1916 also mention a minority being Jain.[The tribes and castes of the Central Provinces of India, by Russell, R. V. and R.B. Hiralal 1916, London : Macmillan and Co., limited, p. 142] Brahmachari Sitalprasad, in his introduction to an edition of the ''Mamala Pahuda'' (Taranpathi Jain text) wrote that one of his used manuscripts was copied in an Asahati temple in 1624. ==Distribution== [[File:Varnijinainagiri.jpg|thumb|Statue of [[Ganeshprasad Varni]] at [[Nainagiri]] ]] The census of India, 1891,Census of India, 1891, Volumes 11-12, India. Census Commissioner, 1893, Table XVI reported 3,071 Asatis in the British ruled districts, of which 450 were Jain. They were mainly present in Jabalpur, Damoh and Sagar, where a significant fraction (27% in Jabalpur) were Jain. Smaller number were present in Bhandara, Gondia, Nagpur and Chhindwara, where all of them were Vaishnava. The community celebrates an annual Asati Diwas.[https://www.bhaskar.com/mp/chhatarpur/news/MP-CHHT-MAT-latest-chhatarpur-news-020505-1260124-NOR.html अखिल भारतीय असाटी महासभा की बैठक में लिए गए महत्वपूर्ण निर्णय, Dainik Bhaskar, Mar 13, 2018] ==Notable figures== [[Ganeshprasad Varni]], one of the foundational figures of the modern North-Indian Digambar intellectual tradition during early 20th century was born into an Asati family.The universe as audience: metaphor and community among the Jains of North India, Ravindra K. Jain, Indian Institute of Advanced Study, 1999, Page 51[https://naidunia.jagran.com/madhya-pradesh/chhatarpur-chhaterpur-news-1313154 महात्मा गांधी की तरह थे गणेश प्रसाद वर्णी, Nai Dunia, 13 Sep 2017] ==See also== *[[Gahoi]] *[[Golapurva]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Social groups of India]] [[Category:Indian castes]] [[Category:Hindu communities]] [[Category:Social groups of Madhya Pradesh]] [[Category:Bania communities]] [[Category:Bundelkhand]]

{{Hinduism}} '''Āśraya''' ([[Sanskrit]]: आश्रय) variously means – base, source, assistance, shelter, protection, refuge, dependence, having recourse to or depending on.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanskrit-English Dictionary|publisher=Spokensanskrit.de|url= http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?script=HK&beginning=0+&tinput=+%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%B6%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%AF&trans=Translate&direction=AU}}</ref> In terms of [[Hindu philosophy]], the living entity or ''[[Jiva]]'' is ''āśraya'', and [[Brahman]] or the Supreme Being, the Godhead, is ''[[Visayah|viśaya]]'', the supreme objective, the goal of life [[Bhagavata Purana]] (VII.x.6). But, this word - ''āśraya'' conveying the primary meaning – 'refuge', immediately relates with the deity which is worshipped rather than with the abstract Brahman, the substratum of all that exists.<ref>{{cite book|title=Ganesapurana|publisher=[[Otto Harrassowitz Verlag]]|page=65|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WcKf113gPwwC&pg=PA520&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I2AKVfnpDMyzuASv9ICwBg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false}}</ref>
==Hindu view-point==
[[Vishishtadvaita|Vishishtadvaita Vedanta]], which promotes qualified-monism, holds the belief that ''[[Jiva]]'' is ''anu'' or [[Arity|monadic]] in substance. ''Jiva'' though infinitesimal, is the individual ''[[Atman (Hinduism)|atman]]'' harboured by a body, which ''atman'' the [[Mundaka Upanishad]] tells us, to be known by the mind is capable of becoming infinite through its attributive knowledge. ''Jiva'' is ''kartā'' and ''bhoktā'', both; it is the ''āśraya'' for ''jñāna'', the substrate for ''krti'' or ''[[prayatna]]'' (effort) caused by the desire to act. Therefore, ''Jiva'' is the ''āśraya'' for the states of experience that invariably involve changes in mental disposition without affecting the ''Jiva''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Vaisnavism: Its Philosophy..|author=S.M.Srinivasa Chari|pages=71–73|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=evmiLInyxBMC&pg=PA73&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1l0KVaPkLdiLuATLtIGoCQ&ved=0CCEQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false}}</ref>
[[Adi Shankara|Shankara]] does not consider ''[[Avidya (Hinduism)|avidyā]]'' (ignorance) as something positively existent, he does not speak about its ''vikśepa-śakti'' (power of dispersion) or ''avarna-sakti'' (power of concealment); he does not raise ''avidyā'' to an eternal metaphysical entity. Shankara also does not subscribe to the view that the individual soul is the bearer of ''avidyā'' (āśraya) or to the contention that the [[Paramatman]] is the ''āśraya'' of ''avidyā'' as is held by [[Maṇḍana Miśra|Mandana]] and [[Vācaspati Miśra|Vācaspati]]. He reiterates that for an awakened person there is no ''avidyā'' to delude and cause pain or pleasure. In the context of the origin of the world (the original state is called ''[[avyakta]]'') he terms Parameswara-Brahman as the āśraya of [[Namarupa|nāmarūpe]] (the physical presence which name manifests) and that Brahman is the āspada (locus) of the cosmic vyavahāra imagined by avidya.<ref>{{cite book|title=Philology and Confrontation|author=Paul Hacker|publisher=[[SUNY Press]]|pages=65, 66, 77|url= https://books.google.co.in/books?id=uP9-Qme_Bo0C&pg=PA65&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1l0KVaPkLdiLuATLtIGoCQ&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false }}</ref>
Knowledge implies the subject which knows and the object that is known. Suppression (''[[avarna]]'') precedes substitution (''[[viksepa]]''); ''avidyā'' makes one misapprehend and therefore it is described as positive (''bhāva-rūpa''), and does not contradict ''[[Vidya (Knowledge)|vidyā]]'' (knowledge). With regard to the transmigrating souls, Shankara does speak about the ''bhūta- āśraya'' or elementary substratum or material substratum of the soul, the subtle body, and about the ''karma- āśraya'' or moral substratum connected with ''vāsanās'' (impressions), ''karma'' (works ordained or forbidden) and ''pūrvaprajñā'' (previous experience) but he does not accept the existence of subtle persisting elements of works or preparatory elements of fruits called ''[[apurva]]'' because of their non-spiritual nature.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of Vedanta Philosophy|author=Subodh Kapoor|publisher=Genesis Publishing|pages=43,300|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=nzdbNqXIxQkC&pg=PA300&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NV8KVay6KIe4uATV5YHIAQ&ved=0CCAQ6AEwATgU#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false}}</ref>
According to the Bhagavata Purana (one of the 18 Mahapuranas or 18 Major Puranas) the personal aspect of God is the Āśraya of the ātmā.
==Jaina viewpoint==
Condition of existence (''gati''), according to [[Jain philosophy]], is the state of a soul shaped by ''gati-nama-karma'' (body-condition-making) or is the cause of the soul passing through any one of the four conditions of existence – hellish, sub-human, human and celestial. They subscribe to the view that in a thing which is permanent the existence of ''sāmānaya'' and ''samavāya'' is complete, that means that common properties cannot exist without individuals possessing them; the individuals are the ''āśraya''; ''sāmānaya'' and ''samavāya'' is complete in one substance will not exist without ''āśraya'' (substratum).<ref>{{cite book|title=Apta-mimamsa of Acharya Samantabhadra|publisher=Bharatiya Jnanapith|pages=30|url= https://books.google.co.in/books?id=KBbt-zzaKKEC&pg=PA124&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1l0KVaPkLdiLuATLtIGoCQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false }}</ref>
==Buddhist view-point==
[[Vasubandhu]] explains that the ''āśraya'' (foundation or support) of the fundamental change that indicates ''ātmabhāva'' (psychophysical continuum) is the non-conceptual wisdom free from the duality of the apprehender and the apprehended; ''āśraya'' refers to obscured ''tathagatagarbha'' (the fourth vajra-point) and its change (''tataparāvrtti'') which is enlightenment (the fifth vajra-point). It is possible to replace one ''āśraya'' with another by freeing the ''[[ayatana]]s'' (internal and external sense- bases) from physical and mental impregnations of negative tendencies which bring about craving, suffering etc., by cultivating calm abiding and superior insight, which process activates the''ayatanas'' associated with awareness (''vidyā'') that purify all impregnations of negative tendencies and involve raising oneself to ''śuddhāśrayabhūmi'', the level of pure superior intention, never to return to the lower realms or suffer rebirth.<ref>{{cite book|title=Mining for Wisdom within Delusion|author=Karl Brunnholzl|publisher=[[Shambhala Publications]]|page=|url= https://books.google.co.in/booksid=W1JbBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT74&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1l0KVaPkLdiLuATLtIGoCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false}}</ref>
''Tathatā'' is the basis of transcendental wisdom, and ''Bhūtatathatā'' is the genuine 'Suchness', the essential nature of phenomenal existence, the self-identical universality, the grounding (''āśraya'') truth of finite particularity. The [[Buddhists]] believe that the ''skandhas'', the ''ayatanas'' and the ''[[Skandha#Eighteen Dh.C4.81tus|dhātu]]s'' are the ''dharmas'' that constitute the phenomenal world and are the forms (and the conditioning factors) in which consciousness appears to itself. ''Bhūtatathatā'' is the ''āśraya'' i.e. the basis which is to be transformed (''āśraya-paravritti''), and also the ''āśraya'' which is the result of the transformation. Therefore, it is the ''āśraya'' of delusion and awakening. The ''Mahāyāna-samparigrahaśāshtra'' tells us that the mind of Reality is ever obstructed by ''āveṇkī avidyā'' which is ''manas'', the seventh consciousness and the ''āśraya'' of ''mano-vijñāna'' and the five sensorial consciousnesses evolved from self-patterning of the Absolute; the attachment of ''manas'' to ''ātmagrāha'' (egohood) and ''dharmagrāha'' (thinghood) makes the perception of the multiplicity of forms possible.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Buddha Nature|author=Brian Edward Brown|publisher=[[Motilal Banarsidass]]|pages=196, 217|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=eXnF2dolnNgC&pg=PA198&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NV8KVay6KIe4uATV5YHIAQ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false }}</ref> The ''Mahāyāna-abhidharmasutra'' tells us that the beginningless ''dhātu'' (locus) is the equal support (''āśraya'') of all phenomena (''dharma'') and rests in the body as seeds. According to the [[Yogacara]]s, ''ātmabhāva'' and ''āśraya'' basically mean – "body", and who also tell us that ''āśraya-paravritti'' can be of the mind or path or errant tendencies.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pruning of the Bodhi Tree|publisher=[[University of Hawaii Press]]|pages=171, 196|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=AjlCz4xm1gIC&pg=PA198&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fmEKVcCyE9GWuASIiYDIBA&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false}}</ref>
==[[Hindu astrology]]==
''Āśarya yoga'', a special kind of planetary placement with most planets resting in moveable or fixed or common signs (''rāsis''), is one of the thirty-two varieties of ''Nabhasa yogas'' in which regard [[Varahamihira]] tells us –
: अनुष्टुभ्-आश्रयोक्तास्तु विफला भवन्त्यन्यैर्विमिश्रताः | : मिश्रा येस्ते फलं दद्युरमिश्राः स्वफलप्रदाः ||
: " The Āśarya yogas become ineffective, when they look like other yogas, and those other yogas become operative and bear results. When the Āśarya yogasdo not bear any resemblance with other yogas, it is then that the Āśarya yogas produce results. " – [[Brihat Jataka]] (XII.12)<ref>{{cite book|title=The Brihajjatakam of Varahamihira|publisher=Genesis Publishing|page=213|url= https://books.google.co.in/books?id=KeS5VkbutFEC&pg=PA213&dq=asraya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I2AKVfnpDMyzuASv9ICwBg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=asraya&f=false }}</ref>

A '''''badchen''''' or '''''badkhn''''' (a Hebrew word meaning [[jester]] that has been Yiddishized as ''badchen'') is a [[Jewish]] comedian with scholarly overtones who entertained guests at weddings among the [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazim]] of [[Eastern Europe]]. Today they are found in all countries with [[Hasidic Judaism|Chassidic]] populations, including the [[United States]], performing their [[shtick]] at weddings.
The ''badchen'' was considered a standard part of the wedding party, as ''de rigueur'' as the officiating [[rabbi]]. An elaborate traditional wedding might also involve a ''letz'' (lit. a clown, here a ''jongleur'' or musician) and a ''marshalik'' (a master of ceremonies).<ref name=Liptzin>[[Sol Liptzin|Liptzin, Sol]], ''A History of Yiddish Literature'', Jonathan David Publishers, Middle Village, NY, 1972, {{ISBN|0-8246-0124-6}}, 22-23.</ref>
The ''badchen'' has to be able both to provide the energy for a party before and after the ceremony itself and also to make the transition to a more serious tone immediately before the ceremony.<ref name=Liptzin/> To this end his comedy was not of a [[slapstick]] variety but rather verbal with many intricate [[Talmud]]ic references and [[in-joke]]s.
Following the Council of Vilna on July 3, 1661, a decree was issued banning merry-making, including the setting of limitations on wedding celebrations, public drinking, fire dances, masquerades, and Jewish comic entertainers. The ''badchen'' was exempted from the decree.<ref>{{Citation | last = Gordon | first = Mel | title = Catastrophe in Ukraine, Comedy Today | newspaper = Reform Judaism | pages = 50–51 | date = Spring 2011 | accessdate = 2011-04-18}}</ref>
Some famous ''badchonim'' include [[Chaim Menachem Mermelstien|Chaim Menachem (Mendel) Mermelstein]] (born March 2, 1920 in [[Mukachevo|Munkacz]], died November 7, 1985 in [[New York City|New York]]), considered the father of modern-day ''badchonus'',{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} and the present-day performers [[Yankel Miller]] and [[Yoel Lebowits]].
The 19th-century [[Broder singer]]s began as ''badchonim'', but soon started to perform outside of the context of weddings. They, in turn, are usually seen as the forerunners of [[Yiddish theater]].
On the Jewish holiday of [[Purim]] many young men undertake to be ''badchonim'' during [[Purim spiel]]s.

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Equatorial Guinea''' begins after [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] wrote letters encouraging taking the religion to Africa in 1916.{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback|publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-8.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 47–59 |origyear = 1916–17}} The first [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] to [[Spanish Guinea]] was Elise Lynelle (then Elise Schreiber) who arrived in [[Bata, Equatorial Guinea|Bata]], Spanish Guinea (as it was called then), on 17 May 1954, and was recognized as a [[Knight of Baha'u'llah]].{{Cite news | title = Obstacles no match for pioneer spirit | newspaper = |location = Malabo, Equatorial Guinea | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 21 August 2004| url = http://news.bahai.org/story/330 | accessdate = 2010-07-30}} In 1968 the first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of [[Equatorial Guinea]] was elected in Santa Isabel, (later renamed [[Malabo]]).{{cite web|last=Dr. Ahmadi |first= |title=Major events of the Century of Light |work=A Study of the Book “Century of Light” |publisher=Association For Bahá’í Studies in Southern Africa |url=http://www.bci.org/bahaistudies/courses/light/time-line-bahai.htm |accessdate=2008-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517111900/http://bci.org/bahaistudies/courses/light/time-line-bahai.htm |archivedate=17 May 2008 }} The community has elected a [[National Spiritual Assembly]] since 1984.{{cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on Research on National Spiritual Assemblies | work = Research notes | publisher = Asia Pacific Bahá'í Studies | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2010-07-31}} The community celebrated its golden jubilee in 2004. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] estimated some 3,500 Bahá'ís in 2005.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions >| publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} ==Beginnings== ===`Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan=== [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916–1917; these letters were compiled together in the book ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The eighth and twelfth of the tablets mentioned[[Africa]] and were written on 19 April 1916 and 15 February 1917, respectively. Publication however was delayed in the United States until 1919—after the end of the [[World War I|First World War]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The tablets were translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on 4 April 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on 12 December 1919.{{cite book | last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}} `Abdu'l-Bahá mentions Bahá'ís traveling "...especially from America to Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia, and travel through Japan and China. Likewise, from Germany teachers and believers may travel to the continents of America, Africa, Japan and China; in brief, they may travel through all the continents and islands of the globe" and " ...the anthem of the oneness of the world of humanity may confer a new life upon all the children of men, and the tabernacle of universal peace be pitched on the apex of America; thus Europe and Africa may become vivified with the breaths of the Holy Spirit, this world may become another world, the body politic may attain to a new exhilaration...."{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-12.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 82–89 |origyear = 1916–17}} ===Establishment of the community=== After the initiation of the [[Ten Year Crusade]], initiated by [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion after the death of 'Abdu'l-Bahá, coordinated efforts to expand the religion across Africa. The first [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] to Spanish Guinea was Elise Lynelle (then Elise Schreiber) who arrived in [[Bata, Equatorial Guinea|Bata]], Spanish Guinea (as it was called then), on 17 May 1954, and was recognized as a [[Knight of Baha'u'llah]]. Because of legal segregation she was unable to meet black Africans. Instead she was able to introduce the teachings of the religion, to a [[Spaniard]], Jose Ramos Espinosa, who accepted the religion. With his assistance she was able to stay in the country longer and in June she sailed to the island of [[Corisco]] as part of her new job. Here she met the elderly King of the island, Santiago Uganda Mdelo and his nephew, Edward Robinson, both of whom readily accepted the religion. King Uganda told Lynelle that he had had a premonition about someone who would come to him with a message. The Bahá'í Community in Equatorial Guinea came under the responsibility of the regional National Spiritual Assembly of North West Africa in 1956.{{cite web | url =http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963|author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 28, 55}}{{Cite web | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = North West Africa | work = Bahá'í Communities by country: Research Notes | publisher = Bahá'í Academic Library Online |url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_communities_country | accessdate = 2010-07-30}} In 1964 the constituent Bahá'í communities were reorganized as the regional assembly of the Bahá'ís of West Central Africa, with its seat in Victoria, comprising the Bahá'ís in the countries and places of Cameroon, Spanish Guinea, St. Thomas Island, Fernando Po Island, Corisco Island, Nigeria, Niger, Dahomey, Togo, and Ghana.{{cite book | last = House of Justice | first = Universal | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Wellspring of Guidance, Messages 1963–1968 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | year = 1976 | location = Wilmette, Illinois | pages = 15, 72 | url = http://bahai-library.com/published.uhj/wellspring.html}} Then in 1967 the National Spiritual Assembly of Cameroon Republic was elected with its seat in Victoria and oversaw the neighboring regions of Spanish Guinea, Fernando Po, Corisco, and São Tomé and Príncipe Islands. This was during a period of wide scale growth in the religion across [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] near the end of the period of [[Colonisation of Africa]].{{cite web|title=Overview of World Religions |work=General Essay on the Religions of Sub-Saharan Africa |publisher=Division of Religion and Philosophy, [[University of Cumbria]] |url=http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |accessdate=2008-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209082606/http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |archivedate=9 December 2007 }} [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|Pioneers]] continued to arrive like Joseph Enonguene and Johanna Ngompex, who came from the [[Bahá'í Faith in Cameroon|Bahá'í community in Cameroon]] in the 1960s. In 1967 in Santa Isabel (later renamed [[Malabo]]), pioneer Hassey Ime lived and helped a community in Fernando Poo island (later renamed[[Bioko]]) and reported an estimated community of at least twenty there.{{cite magazine| title = International News Service |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1968 | issue = 443 | page =20 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1968 the first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of Equatorial Guinea was elected there. American pioneers Mr. and Mrs. George Karch were also members of the community.{{cite magazine| title = New Communities in West Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1969 | issue = 456 | page =5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In June 1969 a local pioneer, Hans Ayukangu, moved to [[Biapa, Equatorial Guinea|Biapa]] on Fernando Poo island where there was a group of four Bahá'ís.{{cite magazine| title = International News Briefs; Equatorial Guinea |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1969 | issue = 456 | page =5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} ==Growth== Formation of the National Spiritual Assembly of Equatorial Guinea 18 July 1973.[http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1963-86_full#254 Messages from the Universal House of Justice 1963–86 ] p. 254, 322, 477 However, between 1972 and 1979 civil society in the country was under duress and religion was repressed (especially progressively from 1975 to 1979). The national assembly was dissolved in 1975-6 by government action. The first citizen on [[Annabon]] a tiny island of Equatorial Guinea, joined the religion in early 1982.{{cite magazine| title = The World; Cameroon |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1982 | issue = 456 | page =12 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Jose Maria Fierro Cueto (also known as Dr. Pepe), came from Mexico to Equatorial Guinea in the 1980s to assist the Baha'i community. Following a change in government the national assembly was reformed in 1984. That same year it was invited to participate as an observer at the first "International Hispanic Congress of Culture" in Bata sponsored by [[UNESCO]]. The Bahá'í community also contributed a statement on topics of the congress like of the role of women in society and the importance of education and unity. The congress was designed to define a cultural aim for Equatorial Guinea and to help make that country better known around the world.{{cite magazine| title = The World; Equatorial Guinea |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1984 | issue = 643 | issn=0195-9212 | page =13 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Joseph Sheppherd was a pioneer to Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, whose circumstances were woven into a book he later wrote which presents the Bahá'í Faith in a context of global change (see [[Bahá'í Faith in fiction]]) and delves into the dynamics of pioneering as a method to gain understanding of spiritual issues compared to social issues, to struggle with a cultural naivete. He served for two years as anthropological adviser to the government and curator of the [[National Ethnological and Archaeological Museum]] in Malabo.{{cite magazine| title = Pioneering; Reaching out to the Family of Man |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1988 |issn=0195-9212 |pages=2–4 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | issue = 693}}, see also

{{Cite web | title = Equatorial Guinea | work = Art history museums of the world | publisher = artschool.com.ru | date = 19 March 2008 |url = http://artschool.com.ru/art_museums/museums_Equatorial_Guinea.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-31 }} ==Modern community== {{Location map+|Equatorial Guinea|float=left|width=220|caption= Cities of [[Equatorial Guinea]] Bahá'ís have held socio-economic development classes in|places= {{location map~|Equatorial Guinea|label=[[Malabo]]|mark=Red star.svg|position=left|lat=3.75|long=8.78|longEW=E}} {{location map~|Equatorial Guinea|label=[[Baney]]|position=right|lat=3.78|long=8.92|longEW=E}} {{location map~|Equatorial Guinea|label=[[Luba, Equatorial Guinea|Luba]]|position=bottom|lat=3.45|long=8.55|longEW=E}} {{Location map~|Equatorial Guinea|label=[[Bata, Equatorial Guinea|Bata]]|position=right|lat=1.85|long=9.75|longEW=E}} }} Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran |work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern.{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} That involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics even then. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. The modern Bahá'í community of Equatorial Guinea has multiplied its interests internally and externally along these lines. It sponsored a functional literacy course for women in Malabo and Bata starting in November 1996. Working with the Ministry of Women and Social Affairs, the community used Bahá'í Centers in Malabo, [[Baney]], [[Luba, Equatorial Guinea|Luba]], and [[Bata, Equatorial Guinea|Bata]]{{Cite web | title = In the Field: Some Examples | work = Social & Economic Development | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | year = 2010 | url =http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-3.html | accessdate = 2010-07-31}} for the courses, which taught literacy as well as reproductive health, nutrition, and basic mathematics.{{Cite journal | title = Around the World, Bahá'í Women's Groups Increase Their Activities |journal = One Country | volume = 1997 | issue = April–June | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | location = | url =http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-4-1.html | issn = | accessdate = 2010-07-31}} In 2004 the community celebrates its golden jubilee celebrations. The national television channel, [[Radio Television Malabo]], covered the event. A monthly magazine, ''[[La Gazzetta]]'', later published an article about the celebrations. Bahá'í citizens of Equatorial Guinea were among those to gather in Yaounde, Cameroon, in a conference called for by the [[Universal House of Justice]] in 2008.{{Cite web| title = The Yaoundé Regional Conference| work = Regional Conferences of the Five Year Plan| publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 29–30 November 2008| url = http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/yaounde.html| accessdate = 2010-07-31}} ===Demographics=== In 2001 [[Operation World]] estimated 0.38%, or 1,720 people were Bahá'ís—and growing at an annual rate of +4.2%.{{cite web|title=Republic of Equatorial Guinea for May 1 |work=Operation World |publisher=Paternoster Lifestyle |year=2001 |url=http://www.operationworld.org/country/equa/owtext.html |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604103106/http://operationworld.org/country/equa/owtext.html |archivedate=4 June 2009 }} In 2004 there were four local assemblies in Equatorial Guinea. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying mostly on the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated nearly 3,552, or 0.5% of the national population, Bahá'ís in 2005. ==See also== *[[Equatorial Guinea#Religion|Religion in Equatorial Guinea]] *[[History of Equatorial Guinea]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bahai.org/worldwide-community/national-communities/equatorial-guinea Equatorial Guinea Bahá'í National Community] {{Africa topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith In Equatorial Guinea}} [[Category:Religion in Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in Africa|Equtorial Guinea]]

Bromo-DragonFLY is considered a potent hallucinogen, having around one third the potency of [[LSD]] with a normal dose in the region of 200 [[μg]] to 800 μg,{{citation needed|reason=The "normal dose" of LSD amount doesn't have citation.|date=January 2016}} and it has an extremely long duration of action, up to several days.<ref name="titleErowid Bromo-Dragonfly Vault : Dosage">{{cite web |url=http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/bromo_dragonfly/bromo_dragonfly_dose.shtml |title=Erowid Bromo-DragonFly Vault : Dosage |accessdate= |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322040809/http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/bromo_dragonfly/bromo_dragonfly_dose.shtml |archivedate=2008-03-22 |df= }}</ref> Bromo-DragonFLY has a [[stereocenter]] and (''R'')-(−)-bromo-DragonFLY is the more active [[stereoisomer]].
==History== Bromo-DragonFLY was first synthesized by Matthew Parker in the laboratory of [[David E. Nichols]] in 1998. As with the earlier and less potent [[dihydrofuran]] series of compounds nicknamed ''FLY'', Bromo-DragonFLY was named after its superficial structural resemblance to a dragonfly.
==Pharmacology== The hallucinogenic effect of bromo-DragonFLY is mediated by its [[agonist]] activity<!-- 93% of 5-HT --> at the [[5-HT2A receptor|5-HT<sub>2A</sub>]] [[5-HT receptor|serotonin receptor]]. Bromo-DragonFLY also has a high [[binding (molecular)|binding]] [[affinity (pharmacology)|affinity]] for the 5-HT<sub>2B</sub> and 5-HT<sub>2C</sub> [[serotonin]] [[receptor (biochemistry)|receptors]], and is most accurately described as a non-subtype selective 5-HT<sub>2</sub> agonist, as it is actually twice as potent an agonist for 5-HT<sub>2C</sub> receptors as for 5-HT<sub>2A</sub>, as well as being less than 5x selective for 5-HT<sub>2A</sub> over 5-HT<sub>2B</sub>.<ref name="pmid9857084">{{cite journal |vauthors=Parker MA, Marona-Lewicka D, Lucaites VL, Nelson DL, Nichols DE |title=A novel (benzodifuranyl)aminoalkane with extremely potent activity at the 5-HT2A receptor |journal=Journal of Medicinal Chemistry |volume=41 |issue=26 |pages=5148–9 |date=December 1998 |pmid=9857084 |doi=10.1021/jm9803525 |url=}}</ref><ref>Corazza O, Schifano F, Farre M, Deluca P, Davey Z, Torrens M, Demetrovics Z, Di Furia L, Flesland L, Siemann H, Skutle A, Van Der Kreeft P, Scherbaum N. Designer drugs on the internet: a phenomenon out-of-control? the emergence of hallucinogenic drug Bromo-Dragonfly. ''Current Clinical Pharmacology''. 2011 May;6(2):125-9. {{PMID|21592070}}</ref> Bromo-DragonFLY is also a MAOI-A inhibitor<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Noble C, Holm NB, Mardal M, Linnet K |title=Bromo-dragonfly, a psychoactive benzodifuran, is resistant to hepatic metabolism and potently inhibits monoamine oxidase A|journal=Toxicology Letters|volume=295|pages=397-407|date=1 October 2018|doi=10.1016/j.toxlet.2018.07.018 |pmid=30036687}}</ref>, and thus strongly inhibits oxidative deamination of 5-HT, increasing its risk profile.
==Dosage== The typical dose of Bromo-DragonFLY is not known, however it has varied from 500 μg to 1 mg.<ref name="titleErowid Bromo-Dragonfly Vault : Dosage"/> It has about 300 times the potency of mescaline, or 1/3 the potency of [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]]. It has been sold in the form of [[Blotting paper|blotters]], similar to the distribution method of LSD, which has led to confusion, and reports of mistakenly consuming Bromo-DragonFly. It has a much longer duration of action than LSD and can last for up to 2–3 days<ref name="titleErowid Bromo-Dragonfly Vault : Dosage"/> following a single large dose, with a slow onset of action that can take up to 6 hours before the effects are felt.

Laboratory testing has confirmed that in October 2009, a batch of Bromo-Dragonfly was distributed, mislabeled as the related compound [[2C-B-FLY]], which is around 20x less potent than BDF by weight. This mistake is believed to have contributed to several lethal overdoses and additional hospitalizations. The batch implicated in these deaths also contained significant synthesis impurities, which may have contributed to the toxicity.<ref name="Erowid 2C-B-Fly Vault: Death Report">{{cite web |url=http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/2cb_fly/2cb_fly_death1.shtml |title=Erowid 2C-B-Fly Vault: Death Report |accessdate= |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013131118/http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/2cb_fly/2cb_fly_death1.shtml |archivedate=2009-10-13 |df= }}</ref>
[[vasoconstriction|Vasoconstrictive]] action resulting from severe overdose of Bromo-DragonFLY is known to have caused tissue [[necrosis]] of the extremities in at least one case. In September 2007, a 35-year-old Swedish male required amputation of the front part of his feet and several fingers on one hand after taking a massive (but unknown) overdose; reportedly, the compound acted as a long-acting efficacious vasoconstrictor, leading to necrosis and [[gangrene]] which became apparent several weeks after the overdose occurred. Treatment was of limited efficacy in this case, although [[tolazoline]] is reportedly an effective treatment where available.<ref>[http://www.lakartidningen.se/engine.php?articleId=9254 Bromo-dragonfly – livsfarlig missbruksdrog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227165926/http://www.lakartidningen.se/engine.php?articleId=9254 |date=2008-12-27 }} (Swedish)</ref><ref>Thorlacius K, Borna C, Personne M. Bromo-dragon fly--life-threatening drug. Can cause tissue necrosis as demonstrated by the first described case. (Swedish). ''Lakartidningen''. 2008 Apr 16-22;105(16):1199-200. {{PMID|18522262}}</ref>
Overdose-associated [[bad trip|disturbing experiences]] and health problems have been described. One case in 2008 in England involved inhalation of vomit, causing nearly fatal [[asphyxia]].<ref>{{cite web |last=George |first=Sallie |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/surrey/7315020.stm |title=England | Surrey | 'I nearly died from taking £5 hit' |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-03-27 |accessdate=2010-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6781aeCi8?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/surrey/7315020.stm |archivedate=2012-04-23 |df= }}</ref> [[Convulsion|Seizures]] have also been reported.<ref name="pmid19876858">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wood DM, Looker JJ, Shaikh L, Button J, Puchnarewicz M, Davies S, Lidder S, Ramsey J, Holt DW, Dargan PI |title=Delayed onset of seizures and toxicity associated with recreational use of Bromo-dragonFLY |journal=Journal of Medical Toxicology |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=226–9 |date=December 2009 |pmid=19876858 |doi= 10.1007/bf03178273|url=|pmc=3550403 }}</ref>
On October 3, 2009, a 22-year-old male from Copenhagen died after ingesting Bromo-dragonfly. His friend described the trip saying, "It was like being dragged to hell and back again. Many times. It is the most evil [thing] I've ever tried. It lasted an eternity." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://jp.dk/indland/kbh/article1884968.ece |title=| Danish man died after trip on Chinese drug |publisher=Jp.dk |date= |accessdate=2010-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6781bqQkL?url=http://jp.dk/indland/kbh/article1884968.ece |archivedate=2012-04-23 |df= }}</ref>
On May 7, 2011, in the United States, two young adults died after overdosing on Bromo-DragonFLY, which they thought was [[2C-E]], and several others were hospitalized during the same incident. Because they took a dosage appropriate for 2C-E, those who took the drug received, in some cases, 100x the normal dose. Both deaths followed seizures, vomiting blood, and terrifying hallucinations. Several surviving victims are reportedly still suffering from its physical effects.<ref name="Two dead, seven injured after designer drug overdose">{{cite web|url=http://www.newson6.com/story/14641463/second-victim-dies-after-taking-designer-drug-in-konawa|title=Second Victim Dies After Taking Designer Drug In Konawa|author=|date=|website=newson6.com|accessdate=26 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327084248/http://www.newson6.com/story/14641463/second-victim-dies-after-taking-designer-drug-in-konawa|archivedate=27 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Drug prohibition laws==
===United States=== Bromo-DragonFLY is listed as a [[Controlled Substances Act#Schedule I controlled substances|Schedule I]] in Oklahoma.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}
===Canada=== Schedule III as of Oct 12 2016. "2C-phenethylamines and their salts, derivatives, isomers and salts of derivatives and isomers that correspond" to a broad definition that includes anything with a 2,5-dimethoxyphenylethamine core. This includes most 2C-s, DOx, TMA, Aleph, NBOMes, NBOHs, NBF, bk-2-C-B, 2C-B-Fly, Bromo-DragonFLY, etc. See http://www.gazette.gc.ca/rp-pr/p2/2016/2016-05-04/html/sor-dors73-eng.php.
===United Kingdom===
Bromo-DragonFLY is widely reported by the media as being a class A drug.<ref name="Man hospitalized after taking £5 high">{{cite news | first = Sallie | last = George | title = 'I nearly died from taking £5 hit' | date = 2008-03-27 | publisher = [[BBC]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/surrey/7315020.stm | work = BBC News | accessdate = 2013-11-28 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6781aeCi8?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/surrey/7315020.stm | archivedate = 2012-04-23 | df = }}</ref> However, as of 2014, it remains unclear to what extent it is covered by the UK phenylethylamine catch-all clause, with commentators noting both the structural similarities<ref>{{cite web|last1=Psychonaut Webmapping Research Group|title=Bromo-Dragonfly Report|url=http://www.psychonautproject.eu/documents/reports/Bromodragonfly.pdf|website=www.psychonautproject.eu/|publisher=Institute of Psychiatry, London|accessdate=12 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515054031/http://psychonautproject.eu/documents/reports/Bromodragonfly.pdf|archivedate=15 May 2012|df=}}</ref> and differences<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erowid.org/ask/ask.php?ID=3103|title=Ask Erowid : ID 3103 : Does Bromo-Dragonfly fall under the UK ban on phenethylamines?|author=|date=|website=www.erowid.org|accessdate=26 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324030327/https://www.erowid.org/ask/ask.php?ID=3103|archivedate=24 March 2018|df=}}</ref> to the phenylethylamine class. If the prosecution could demonstrate structural similarity in court, it would be considered a Class A substance<ref>{{cite web|last1=Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs|title=Consideration of the Novel Psychoactive Substances (‘Legal Highs’)|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/119139/acmdnps2011.pdf|publisher=UK Home Office|accessdate=12 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714133535/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/119139/acmdnps2011.pdf|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=}}</ref> but as a benzodifuran it is significantly different to this class. It is not explicitly named in the misuse of drugs act.<ref name="UK MoDA">{{cite web | url = http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1971/38/schedule/2 | title = UK Misuse of Drugs Act 1971 > 1971 c. 38 > SCHEDULE 2 | accessdate = 2013-11-28 | author = [[UK Home Office]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DGsEFW0c?url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1971/38/schedule/2 | archivedate = 2012-12-29 | df = }}</ref> It would be covered by the UK [[Psychoactive Substances Act 2016]].
===Sweden=== [[Riksdag|''Sveriges riksdag'']] added Bromo-Dragonfly to schedule IV (''"substances, plant materials and fungi with medical use"'') as narcotics in Sweden as of Jan 3, 2008, published by [[Medical Products Agency (Sweden)|''Medical Products Agency'']] in their regulation '''LVFS 2007:14''' listed as '''Bromo-Dragonfly, brombensodifuranyl-isopropylamin'''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lakemedelsverket.se/upload/lvfs/LVFS_2007-14.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928024105/http://www.lakemedelsverket.se/upload/lvfs/LVFS_2007-14.pdf |archivedate=2013-09-28 |df= }}</ref> Bromo-DragonFLY was first classified as "health hazard" by [[Riksdag|''Sveriges riksdags'']] health ministry [[:sv:Statens folkhälsoinstitut|''Statens folkhälsoinstitut'']] under the act [[:sv:Lagen om förbud mot vissa hälsofarliga varor|''Lagen om förbud mot vissa hälsofarliga varor'']] (translated ''Act on the Prohibition of Certain Goods Dangerous to Health'') as of Jul 15, 2007, in their regulation '''SFS 2007:600''' listed as '''brombensodifuranylisopropylamin (Bromo-Dragonfly)''', making it illegal to sell or possess.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/sfs/20070600.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929062843/http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/sfs/20070600.pdf |archivedate=2013-09-29 |df= }}</ref>
===Denmark=== On December 3, 2007 the drug was banned in Denmark.<ref name="Danish Medicines Agency">{{cite web|url=http://www.dkma.dk/1024/visUKLSArtikel.asp?artikelID=12407|title=Amendment of Executive Order on Euphoriant Substances|publisher=[[Danish Medicines Agency]]|year=2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6781eHW6Y?url=http://www.dkma.dk/da?sc_itemid=%7BF2733320-09EF-4477-AA70-0725C65FD9FD%7D|archivedate=2012-04-23|df=}}</ref> The substance has been declared illegal by health minister [[Jakob Axel Nielsen]], following recommendations from the Danish Health Ministry. It is currently classified as a dangerous narcotic and therefore its possession, manufacture, importation, supply or usage is strictly prohibited. Anyone involved in such activities can face legal action.<ref name="titleErowid Bromo-Dragonfly Vault : Legal Status">{{cite web |url=http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/bromo_dragonfly/bromo_dragonfly_law.shtml#denmark |title=Erowid Bromo-Dragonfly Vault : Legal Status |accessdate= |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415151312/http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/bromo_dragonfly/bromo_dragonfly_law.shtml#denmark |archivedate=2008-04-15 |df= }}</ref>
===Norway=== Bromo-DragonFLY is currently on the Norwegian narcotics list,.<ref name="titleList of narcotic drugs according to Norwegian law">{{cite web |url=http://www.lovdata.no/for/sf/ho/to-19780630-0008-001.html |title=List of narcotic drugs according to Norwegian law |accessdate= |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6781fL9h1?url=http://www.lovdata.no/for/sf/ho/to-19780630-0008-001.html |archivedate=2012-04-23 |df= }}</ref><ref name="titleLegemiddelverket about Bromo-DragonFLY">{{cite web|url=http://www.legemiddelverket.no/templates/InterPage____57471.aspx|title=Statens Legemiddelverk about derivates and Bromo-DragonFLY|accessdate=|work=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528230605/http://www.legemiddelverket.no/templates/InterPage____57471.aspx|archivedate=2009-05-28|df=}}</ref> Thus it is effectively a narcotic drug by Norwegian law.
===Poland===
Currently, Bromo-DragonFLY is an uncontrolled substance in Poland.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}}
===Romania=== The chemical compound has been added as an illegal substance under the Law 143/2000 on February 10, 2010.<ref name="titleModified Romanian law 143/2000 on January 10, 2010.">{{cite web |url=http://www.legestart.ro/Ordonanta-de-urgenta-6-2010-modificarea-completarea-Legii-143-2000-prevenirea-combaterea-traficului-consumului-ilicit-droguri-completarea-Legii-339-2005-regimul-juridic-plantelor-(MzQ3MzAw).htm |title=Modified Romanian law 143/2000 on January 10, 2010. |accessdate=February 28, 2010 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624223623/http://www.legestart.ro/Ordonanta-de-urgenta-6-2010-modificarea-completarea-Legii-143-2000-prevenirea-combaterea-traficului-consumului-ilicit-droguri-completarea-Legii-339-2005-regimul-juridic-plantelor-%28MzQ3MzAw%29.htm |archivedate=June 24, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
===Australia=== As of 9 September 2011, Bromo-DragonFLY was added to Schedule 2 of the Queensland Drugs Misuse Regulation 1987.<ref name="Queensland Drugs Misuse Regulation 1987">{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.qld.gov.au/LEGISLTN/CURRENT/D/DrugsMisuseR87.pdf |title=Queensland Drugs Misuse Regulation 1987 |accessdate= |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110422124116/http://www.legislation.qld.gov.au/LEGISLTN/CURRENT/D/DrugsMisuseR87.pdf |archivedate=2011-04-22 |df= }}</ref>
Nationally, the drug is listed under Schedule 9 (Prohibited) of the Poisons Standard. Accordingly, the drug is prohibited in all states and territories.<ref name="Poisons Standard">Poisons Standard October 2015 {{cite web |url=https://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2015L01534 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-01-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119074606/https://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2015L01534/ |archivedate=2016-01-19 |df= }}</ref>
===Finland=== As of 12 March 2012, Bromo-DragonFLY is an illegal designer drug.<ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/2012/03/muuntohuumeita_nyt_ensi_kertaa_huumausaineluetteloon_3298251.html?origin=rss Design drugs] {{fi icon}}</ref>

{{italic title}} '''''Cabildo''''' is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] magazine which is considered the main press organ of [[nationalism|nationalist]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholicism]] in the country. First published in the 1970s and then inactive during most of the 1990s, the magazine has become notorious for its [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] and [[anti-Semitism|anti-Semitic]] editorial line.
==History== The first issue of ''Cabildo'' was published on 17 May 1973, eight days before the democratically elected [[President of Argentina|president]] [[Héctor Cámpora]] took office after several years of military [[dictatorship]]. In this stage the magazine consistently demanded the return to military rule through a new [[coup d'état]]. Not long afterwards, President Cámpora resigned, leaving the way open for [[Juan Perón]] to return to the country from exile and be elected president. After Perón's death, the government of his wife and vice-president [[Isabel Perón]] ordered ''Cabildo'' to be closed down on three occasions. <ref name="saborido">Jorge Saborido, 2004. [http://www.ucm.es/BUCM/revistas/ghi/11328312/articulos/RCHA0404110209A.PDF El antisemitismo en la Historia argentina reciente: la revista Cabildo y la conspiración judía] {{es icon}}</ref>
The magazine returned after the military coup of 1976 that started the [[National Reorganization Process]], and became almost regularly a monthly publication. The June 1977 issue, however, was retired from circulation by the government, and the July issue was cancelled, because ''Cabildo'' had covered the [[kidnapping]] of journalist [[Jacobo Timerman]], which the dictatorship wanted to pass as a legal detention.
The magazine was notoriously anti-Semitic and supported the idea of a global [[Zionism|Zionist]] conspiracy and blamed [[Jew]]s in Argentina for the violence of left-wing [[guerrilla]] insurgents, employing common [[stereotype]]s of Jews and well-known [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]] to accuse Jews of funding [[Marxism|Marxist]] organizations.<ref name="saborido" /><ref>Marguerite Feitlowitz, quoted by Leonardo Senkman, 1989. [http://www.tau.ac.il/eial/IV_1/feitlowitz.htm El antisemitismo en la Argentina] {{es icon}}</ref>
''Cabildo'' continued being published after the return to democratic rule in 1983. Among its frequent collaborators was General [[Ramón Camps]], former head of the [[Buenos Aires Provincial Police]] and guilty of multiple crimes (including 32 murders), for which he was eventually amnestied.
Since 1989, the critical economic situation of Argentina caused the magazine to be released irregularly. In 1991 it was discontinued, but it was restarted in 1998 with part of the original staff and some new collaborators. <ref name="saborido"/>
''Cabildo'' continues being published. Its editorial line focuses on current topics, such as the [[reproductive health]] policies of President [[Néstor Kirchner]], and his sometimes tense relations with the [[Roman Catholicism in Argentina|Argentine Catholic Church]]. It supports [[Catholic traditionalism|ultra-conservative]] (pre-[[Second Vatican Council|Vatican II]]) Catholic teachings, and criticizes the [[human rights]] stance of the government with regard to the crimes committed by the armed forces during the [[Dirty War]]. The magazine also advertises courses and seminaries with a [[fascism|fascist]] ideological orientation, usually held on Catholic Church facilities. A review of a 2005 issue in the leftist newspaper ''Página/12'' claimed that ''Cabildo'' "works like the repressed [[unconscious mind|unconscious]] that says what the Catholic right thinks."<ref>Página/12. 11 December 2005. [http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-60354-2005-12-11.html "Cabildo", o el retorno de lo reprimido conservador y católico] {{es icon}}</ref>

{{Infobox rebbe | title = | image = Chaim Leib Shmuelevitz.jpg | caption = | term = | full name = | main work = | predecessor = | successor = | spouse1 = | issue1 = | spouse2 = | issue2 = | spouse3 = | issue3 = | dynastyname = | father = | mother = | birth_date = 1902 | birth_place = [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]] | death_date = 2 January 1979 | death_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] | date of burial = | place of burial = [[Har HaMenuchot]] |}} '''Chaim Leib Halevi Shmuelevitz''', ({{lang-he|חיים לייב שמואלביץ}} ;1902–1979),<ref name=J.Obs>{{cite web |url=http://www.eilatgordinlevitan.com/kovno/kovno_pages/kovno_stories_shmulevitz.html |title=Rabbi Chaim Leib Shmulevitz |author=Eliahu Meir Klugman}}</ref> -- also spelled Shmulevitz, in Hebrew שמולביץ -- was a member of the faculty of the [[Mir Yeshiva (Poland)|Mirrer Yeshiva]] for more than 40 years,<ref>"For fifty years..." {{cite web |url=http://www.jewishusedbooks.com/prodview.asp?idProduct=14182 |title=The Rosh Yeshiva: The story of Rav Chaim Shmulevitz}}</ref> in [[Poland]], [[Shanghai]] and [[Jerusalem]], serving as [[Rosh yeshiva]] during its sojourn in [[Shanghai]] from 1941 to 1947, and again in the [[Mir yeshiva (Jerusalem)|Mirrer Yeshiva]] in Jerusalem from 1965 to 1979. He taught, guided, and inspired thousands of disciples throughout his lifetime, by word and deed, with legendary diligence and intensity in [[Torah]] study.
==Early years== Shmuelevitz was born on the second day of [[Rosh Hashana]] 5663 (3 October 1902) in [[Kovno]], Lithuania,<ref name=J.Obs/> to Rabbi Refoel Alter Shmuelevitz and Ettel (née Horowitz), a daughter of Rabbi [[Yosef Yozel Horwitz]], known as the Alter of [[Novardok yeshiva|Novhardok]]. The [[sandek]] at his [[bris milah]] was Rabbi [[Yitzchok Blazer]] ("Reb Itzele Peterburger"), a Torah and [[mussar movement|mussar]] luminary of the time, who was one of Rabbi [[Yisrael Salanter]]'s greatest disciples.
In Chaim Leib's youth, his family moved to [[Shchuchyn|Stutchin]]. Until the age of 16, he was educated by his father, who was one of the leading yeshiva lecturers in Lithuania. In 1919 Rabbi Refoel Alter, who was then the rosh yeshiva of ''Shaarei Torah'' in [[Grodno]], died suddenly. Within a very short time, his mother died too, orphaning Chaim Leib, his younger brother Shlomo, and two sisters.
Rabbi Refoel Alter's position at the yeshiva was taken up by Rabbi [[Shimon Shkop]]. Chaim Leib developed a close bond with Rabbi Shkop. At the age of 18, Chaim Leib's mentor invited him to deliver the third-level [[Shiur (Torah)|shiur]] in the preparatory academy at the yeshiva. Shmuelevitz held this position for a few years before transferring to the yeshiva in [[Mir Yeshiva (Poland)|Mir]]. Many of his students of those years later became great Torah leaders, and his own four years in Grodno with Rabbi Shkop had a profound influence on his approach to Talmudic analysis.
At the age of 22, Shmuelevitz headed a group of students who transferred from Grodno to [[Mir Yeshiva (Poland)|Mir]]. In accordance with the contemporary practice in the yeshiva world, Chaim Leib became known as Chaim Stutchiner,<ref>"known as R' Chaim Stutchiner." {{cite web |title=Hilchos Aveilus |url=http://download.yutorah.org/2012/4705/777806.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torahtavlin.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/20-Tetzaveh10.pdf |title=Shabbos Parshas Tetzaveh - Parshas Zachor |date=March 7, 2009}}</ref> after the [[shtetl]] in which he grew up. The Mirrer rosh yeshiva, Rabbi [[Eliezer Yehuda Finkel (Mir rosh yeshiva, Poland and Jerusalem)|Eliezer Yehuda Finkel]], set his sights on Shmuelevitz as his eventual spiritual heir. He set the seal on this future appointment by offering his student the hand of his daughter in marriage.
Shmuelevitz married Chana Miriam,<ref name=Invit>>name on 1930 wedding invitation: {{cite web |url=https://www.kedem-auctions.com/content/invitation-rabbi-chaim-shmuelevitz-his-wedding-%E2%80%93-mir-1930 |title=Invitation from Rabbi Chaim Shmuelevitz to his Wedding – Mir, 1930}}</ref> the rosh yeshiva's daughter, on the last day of [[Hanukkah]], 3 Tevet 5690 (3 January 1930).<ref>His Petira was also on that date, his 49th wedding anniversary</ref> A scant few years later, at the relatively young age of 31, Shmuelevitz was appointed as a [[maggid shiur]], delivering regular lectures. Rabbi Shmuelevitz's lectures were modeled on the study strategy of his erstwhile mentor, Rabbi Shimon Shkop, personalized in a style of his own. The hallmark of his lectures was depth combined with a fabulous breadth; it was not uncommon for him to cite 20 or 30 different sources from far-flung corners of the [[Talmud]] and its commentaries during a single shiur. These shiurim attracted a wide audience, including some of the most advanced students in Mir.
==World War II== With the outbreak of [[World War II]], Mir Yeshiva was forced into exile. The students and faculty fled from [[Mir, Belarus|Mir]] to [[Vilnius|Vilna]], where they stayed for about two months, after which they moved to [[Keidan]], where they managed to set up the yeshiva once more in 1940. After being ordered out of Keidan seven months later by the [[Communism|Communist]] authorities, the yeshiva divided into four groups,<ref name=R.Leiman>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Jewish Press |date=July 17, 1998 |author=Rabbi Yehoshua Leiman |title=JEWISH HISTORY: Rav Chaim Leib Shmulevitz, Part III - Shanghai |page=57}}</ref><ref>The article cites ''Operation Torah Rescue'' by Rabbi Yechezkel Leitner, and the latter is cited in: {{cite web |url=http://www.chareidi.org/archives5759/vayikro/features.htm |title=Dei'ah veDibur - Information & Insight}}</ref> each numbering between eighty and one hundred students. Rabbi Shmuelevitz's shiurim continued virtually without interruption throughout the early period of World War II, while when the yeshiva was continually in transit. In late 1940, hundreds of Mir yeshiva students obtained [[Visa (document)|visas]] from [[Chiune Sugihara]] to travel via [[Siberia]] and [[Vladivostok]] to [[Japan]].
The yeshiva stayed in [[Kobe]], [[Japan]], for about six months, and then relocated to Shanghai for the next five years. Although living conditions were extremely difficult, the yeshiva prospered. As Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Finkel had gone to [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]] to obtain visas for the yeshiva and was forced to remain there, Rabbi Shmuelevitz and the [[Mashgiach ruchani|mashgiach]], Rabbi [[Yechezkel Levenstein]], assumed responsibility for the day-to-day running of the yeshiva.
==Shanghai== [[File:Mir Shanghai.jpg|thumb|200px|The yeshiva in the [[Beth Aharon Synagogue]], Shanghai; Rabbi Shmuelevitz is seated in the front row, second from right]] Somehow, Rabbi Shmuelevitz became responsible for the financial needs of all Jewish learning institutions in the city, not just his own. These included contingents of the famed yeshivas of [[Kamyanyets|Kamenetz]], [[Kletzk]], [[Tomchei Temimim|Lubavitch]], and [[Chachmei Lublin Yeshiva|Lublin]].<ref name=J.Obs/> This was despite the fact that exchanging foreign currency in Shanghai was fraught with danger and Rabbi Shmuelevitz lived with a perpetual fear of being apprehended by the authorities.
A short while after arriving in [[Shanghai]], Rabbi Shmuelevitz received American visas only for himself and his family. He refused them, saying that he would leave only when all the students had received their visas. This ultimately meant staying in Shanghai for five and a half years.
These and other details were part of the 1966 testimony given by Rav Chaim Shmulevitz and his wife to [[Yad VaShem]].<ref name=Yated/>
==Move to Jerusalem== In 1947 the yeshiva moved again — as always, as a single unit — this time, to the [[United States]], where Rabbi Shmuelevitz spent six months before rejoining his father-in-law, Rabbi Eliezer Yehudah Finkel, in the Mirrer Yeshiva in Jerusalem.<ref name=J.Obs/> <ref name=R.Leiman/> For the next 32 years, until his death in 1978, Rabbi Shmuelevitz remained in Mir-Jerusalem, disseminating his unique wisdom and insight to thousands of disciples.
He became active in [[World Agudath Israel|Agudath Israel]] in Israel, and its ''Moetzes Gedolei HaTorah'' (Council of Torah Sages) on which he served.<ref name=R.Leiman/> He also became the father-in-law of Rabbi [[Nochum Partzovitz]], his successor as ''rosh yeshiva''.
==Personality== Rabbi Shmuelevitz was well known for his ability to become totally engrossed in his [[Torah]] study for hours at a time. His ethical discourses, many of which have been published in [[English language|English]], are considered classics. They offer novel interpretations and reveal his penetrating insights into human nature.
Besides being regarded as a leading Torah scholar, Shmulevitz was famed for his sterling character and all-encompassing concern for his fellow Jews.
Rabbi Shmuelevitz's respect for his father was legendary and he quoted him often in both Torah lectures and [[musar literature|mussar]] discourses. He considered his father's handwritten Torah ''chiddushim'' (new Torah insights) his most valued possessions. During the [[Six-Day War]], when the yeshiva was within range of [[Arab Legion|Jordanian]] artillery fire, Rabbi Shmuelevitz sent some of the manuscripts to America with his uncle, Rabbi [[Avraham Yoffen]], with specific instructions that he carry them by hand and not put them in his luggage, because, "''Dos iz meyn gantze leben'' (This is my whole life)."
==Family== His youngest son, Rav Meir Shmulevitz, lives in [[Kiryat Mattersdorf]], Jerusalem, and R'Chaim's son Avrohom Shmulevitz is a [[Rosh mesivta]] at the [[Mir Yeshiva (Jerusalem)|Mirrer Yeshiva]].<ref name=Yated>{{cite newspaper|newspaper=Yated Neeman |date=December 24, 2014 |author=Tzvi Yaakovson |title=Rav Chaim Shmulevitz zt"l On His Holocaust Rescue |url=https://yated.com/rav-chaim-shmulevitz-ztae%C2%9Dl-on-his-holocaust-rescue-the-yated-speaks-to-rav-meir-shmulevitz}}</ref> Both were born in Israel.
Of their older siblings, Rebbetzin Partzovitz and Rebbetzin Ezrachi, were born in Mir, as was their brother Rav Refoel, Z"L.<ref>Niftar 5776. {{cite web |author=Tzvi Yaakovson |date=January 20, 2016 |title=Rav Refoel Shmulevitz Zt"l - "My Job in This World Is to Teach Torah" |url=https://yated.com/804-2}}</ref> Their sister Rebbetzin Weiss was born in Shanghai.
==Final days== [[File:Grave of Chaim Leib Shmuelevitz.jpg|thumb|His gravesite at [[Har HaMenuchot]].]] A few days after [[Sukkot]] 1978, Rabbi Shmuelevitz was rushed to the hospital and, for the next two months, his life hung by a thread. Even during the weeks of semi-consciousness his lips moved, and from time to time he could be heard mumbling words of Torah. Rabbi [[Moshe Feinstein]] said, "The world rested upon Reb Chaim's shoulders." Jews worldwide prayed for his recovery. Two months later on the third of [[Tevet]],<ref name=Invit/><ref>his 49th wedding anniversary</ref> Rabbi Shmuelevitz died at the age of 76. Nearly 100,000 mourners attended his [[funeral]]. <ref name=R.Leiman/> He is buried on [[Har HaMenuchot]].
During his lifetime, Rabbi Shmuelevitz committed to paper his every lecture and public address, leaving behind at his death thousands of handwritten pages, including ''chiddushim'' on every tractate of the Talmud.

[[File:Uldine Utley.png|thumb|180px|Child preacher [[Uldine Utley]], aged about 12]] In some branches of [[Christianity]], especially American [[pentecostalism]], children are occasionally [[preacher]]s, or even [[Ordination|ordained]] [[Minister (Christianity)|ministers]]. The heyday of child preachers was in the 1920s and 1930s,<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|last1=Hebblethwaite|first1=Cordelia|title=The curious allure of child preachers|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-19377143|accessdate=17 May 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|date=29 August 2012}}</ref> but a number of videos of modern-day child preachers can be seen on YouTube.<ref name=ABC>{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Dan|last2=Murphey|first2=Chris|title=Boy Preacher, 11, Says Skeptics Make Him 'More Determined to Stay in Christ'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/boy-preacher-11-skeptics-make-determined-stay-christ/story?id=17018767|accessdate=17 May 2016|work=[[ABC News]]|date=16 August 2012}}</ref>
One of the most prominent child preachers was [[Marjoe Gortner]], who was the subject of the 1972 documentary ''[[Marjoe]]''.
According to [[Randall Balmer]], the appeal of having child preachers is in its novelty, making it "a kind of a carnival side-show".<ref name=BBC />
In 2012, when he was 11 years old, [[Ezekiel Stoddard]] was ordained as a minister in his family's non-denominational Fullness of Time Church, in Maryland.<ref name>https://www.bbc.com/news/av/magazine-19259774/ezekiel-stoddard-11-year-old-preacher-and-minister</ref>
In 2011, [[National Geographic (U.S. TV channel)|National Geographic]] aired a documentary that featured a four-year-old preacher in the [[United Pentecostal Church International]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Stephen|title=Documentary shines light on pint-sized preachers|url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/08/17/pint-sized-preachers/|accessdate=30 July 2017|work=[[CNN]]|date=17 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pint-Sized Preachers|url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/videos/pint-sized-preachers/|publisher=[[National Geographic (U.S. TV channel)|National Geographic]]|accessdate=30 July 2017}}</ref> And From 2017 a 14 years adolescent boy named Michael Santhosh, living in Sri kalahasti of India, is being famous for his debates and sermons in Christ Lutheran Church.

[[File:Imm logo.jpg|thumb|Church of World Messianity]] The '''Church of World Messianity''' (世界救世教 ''Sekai Kyūsei Kyō'' in [[Japanese language|Japanese]]), abbreviated '''COWM''', is a [[Japanese new religions|Japanese new religion]] founded in 1935 by [[Mokichi Okada]]. There are three pillars of the religion, of which the key concept is [[johrei]], claimed to be a method of channeling divine light into the body of another for the purposes of [[healing]]. The Art of Nature which includes nature farming, and the Art of Beauty which includes practices such as Ikebana, a form of Japanese flower arranging, are the other formal practices. In 1926, Okada claimed to have received a divine [[revelation]] that empowered him to be a channel of God's Healing Light (''johrei'') to purify spiritual realm to remove the spiritual causes of illness, poverty, and strife from the world and inaugurate a new [[Messianic Age]]. He went on to teach Johrei to his followers allowing them also to achieve Messianity and spread the teachings across the world. Members are given permission to channel Johrei by wearing an O-Hikari pendant which contains a copy of one of Mokichi Okada's calligraphies. He is often referred to as "Meishu-Sama" (enlightened spiritual teacher) by his followers.
Okada's teaching is represented by a number of his works, such as Foundation of Paradise and ''Johrei: Divine Light of Salvation'', which has been edited and translated by the Society of Johrei, an offshoot of COWM.
The movement currently claims 800,000 followers, including many in Brazil. ''[[Shinji Shumeikai]]'' {{Nihongo||神慈秀明会}}, also known as ''Shumei'', also follows the teachings of Okada and is considered a descendant of the church by CFAR.<ref>[http://www.thecenters.org/searchgroups.aspx?groupid=167 Centers for Apologetics Research (CFAR) – International Countercult Ministries > Search Groups<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606041730/http://www.thecenters.org/searchgroups.aspx?groupid=167 |date=2011-06-06 }}</ref>
According to [[Anthropology of religion|anthropologist of religion]] Winston Davis, [[Mahikari]] groups are comparable to Church of World Messianity and follow basically the same healing ritual.<ref>{{harvnb|Davis|1980|pp=75–76}}</ref>
== In Brazil == [[File:Solo Sagrado Guarapiranga.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Church of World Messianity in [[Guarapiranga]] ]]
Brazil has the largest concentration of Japanese and people of Japanese descent outside Japan. According to Hideaki Matsuoka, University of California, Berkeley, in a presentation at the Summer 2000 Asian Studies Conference Japan entitled "Messianity Makes the Person Useful: Describing Differences in a Japanese Religion in Brazil," Japanese new religions have propagated in Brazil since the 1930s and they now have at least a million non-Japanese Brazilian followers. Four major religions ranked by the number of followers are [[Seicho-no-Ie]], Messianity, Mahikari and [[PL Kyodan]].
In Brazil, [[Guarapiranga]] is the sacred place of the Church of World Messianity ({{lang-pt|Igreja Messiânica Mundial}}).
